text: Sampled at GABF 2015. From my notes. In sample glass hazy gold. White head. Nose of sour ripe stone fruit and cirrus. Medium body. Flavor is quite sour with tastes like lemon, apricots, ,and grapes all fermented. Quite tasty and overall an excellent beer.
Hazy golden color with a small, white head that left light lacing on the glass. Aroma of earth must, funk, brett, wood, bacteria. Taste of wood, bacteria, bretts, basement, and a sour finish.

Bottle shared at Struise shop Brugge. Cloudy orange with a medium white head. Aroma has a lot of dusty cellar funk, cobweb, lactic, light leathery notes and citrus. Flavour is light heavy acidic. Light medium bodied with light carbonation.

Refrigerated 75 cl brown bottle corked and capped. Clear light orange with medium white head. Aroma is light tart, medium body, well carbonated, thick small-bubble lacing. Taste is nice tart citrus, oak, and some white wine.

Shared at a tasting hosted by Steve Hackley on September 25. Thanks Steve! This was poured from a 750 mL bottle. The pour on this is a foggy gold with no head and no lace. Its almost like pouring a light syrup. The aroma is way sour. I dont know that Ive smelled one this intense before. There is a little citrus, some nice funk, and a little wine that shows through on the back end. Its to the point where there is so much sour happening, its almost sweet. Should be interesting. The flavor is pretty disappointing. There is a lacto-induced sourness to start and some of the aiding flavors just fade away. The bright citrus is reserved, its not as sour as the nose would lead on either. The mouth feel is light and crisp, but the lack of carbonation makes it come off a little syrupy. The aftertaste is lingeringly funky and sour with a decent amount of citrus, but it is not what I was hoping for. Upland needs the fruit!

Bottle poured at GABF 2015 with Andrew, Mel and Frank. Pours a hazy golden body with thick, creamy white lacing. Aroma is bright sour fruit. Mouthfeel is light and soft with notes of tart fruit and mild vinegar in the finish.

750 ml bottle Blend 1. Pours a cloudy dark orange color and topped by a small head of off white foam that settles quickly to a thin film and leaves some steaks of lace around the glass. The aroma is of sour citrus, lemon peel, lime, barnyard funk, vinous oak, and lactic sourness. The flavor follows and is really nice and sour with notes of citrus fruit, lemon peel and lime, acetic sourness, and vinous oak. There is a nice lactic sourness as well that keeps things from getting too acetic. Medium bodied with puckering sourness and ample carbonation that leads to a dry, sour citrus finish. I was really surprised by this. Really nice sour beer and hope to try the other blends some day.

Great Taste of the Midwest, 2015. I am not sure what year this is. Great beer, appearance, palate, aroma and flavor are all correct, and it is hard to get much closer to a Belgian lambic than this; in fact it could pass for real lambic. Very sour, yeast in the aroma, dry and earthy.

25/VII/15 - 75cl bottle @ Trillium tasting, home - BB: n/a (2015-998) Thanks to 77ships for sharing the bottle!
Little hazy orange beer, small creamy aery off-white head, unstable, dissipates immediately, non adhesive. Aroma: funky, spicy, hint of cinnamon, chlorine, bit chemical, some unripe apricots. MF: ok carbon, medium body. Taste: very sour start, some apple cider vinegar, sourish, lemon juice. Aftertaste: bitter touch, woody, some tannins, very sour, lemon juice, vinegar. My enamel is crumbling down...

75cl bottle courtesy of and shared with Tdereock via Adamjackson.
Orangée, col fin blanc.
Arôme de brett, lacto, belle note dagrumes avec un léger rétro rustique et boisé.
Palais est aigre mais plaisant par rapport à dautres bières de Upland. Agrumes, brett avec un léger côté abricot. Fini est sec, légèrement épicé avec une pointe boisée de chêne. Retrouve un profil assez américain, principalement avec cet usage de brett. Reste très correcte et une bonne bière dentrée dans les bières Upland qui réservent souvent des surprises très vinaigrées. Blend 5.

Thanks to tderoeck & AdamChandler! Drank a good amount from a 750 ml. bottle. Sour Blend nr. 5. Hazy orange, little white head. Nose is puckering sour, lime & lemon acidy, strong acidity, light barnyard, more sourness & acidity, Strongly sour but nowhere near as unbearable as I was lead to believe that it would be. Strong, puckering basic sourness, no real complexity but enjoyable for me. Taste is basic puckering lemon acidity, USA sour, hay, faint barnyard but overall puckering lemon acidity & some vinegar, oak & more tartness, Body is puckering USA acidity, some vinegar, lower carb. Drinks quite well despite the strong acidity of it all.

From a bottle at the Funk Asheville Festival 2015. Version #6. Pours a cloudy gold with an off white head. Flavors of tart yellow cherries. Touch of sweetness in the finish. My favorite of the festival.

Bottle thanks to chebyshev, shared with Luk. Clear pale gold pour with generous white foam. Aroma is quite acetic, funky, lots of oak, light white wine notes, wet hay, nice profile but with a strong american sour acetic component. Taste is tart and acidic, lemony, acetic flavors, light oak notes soften the touch on the palate. Palate is med-light bodied with good carbonation, nice dryness. Overall quite easy drinking, very approachable sour.
Light hazy yellow pour with a white head. Massive sour nose with an underlying funk. Tart, but not bracingly so. Soft finish with some lingering acidity. Slightly funky.
750ml bottle pours out a hazy straw topped with a small white head. Nose is burning tires some fruit notes and lots of funk. Taste is kiwi sour tart funk and a nice acidic kick.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2016 Blend #2, moderately sour without being overly acidic, which is a departure from the recent upland Ive tried. lemon, pineapple, tropical fruit.  3.21.15

Blend #6 - medium sour without all the upland acid, which is nice when they can show restraint.  butter, lemon, oak.  Tasty.
Bottle - Blend 5 - Light petroleum and apricot. Cloudy gold with a decent white head. White grape, apricot and a nice sourness. Very nicely balanced and easy drinking.

Quite the beer. Pours a muddy burnt orange. Aromas are pickle juice, vinegar, wine. Flavors are blue cheese, olives, vinegar, lemon juice, pickles, oak, and some funk. Interesting. Very sour.. But not a surprise from these guys.

Bottle, courtesy of b3shine (thanks a lot Beau!), shared with Dave. Very hazy orange-gold with a lively off white head. Lovely funk, some musty cork, horse blanket, light leather, light rubber. Delicious!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Bottle..pour is golden with a white head...Nose is vanilla, french oak, pineapple, tart...Taste tart, banana, oak, mango, sweetness..

Pours a hazy gold with a fleeting white head. The aroma is acidic and sour with hay and barnyard notes. The flavor is tart and refreshing with berry and barnyard characteristics. Sour/tart puckering mouthfeel with no astringency. Light body with high carbonation. The finish is dry and cleansing. Excellent sour.

Side by side tasting of the Upland Sour Reserve, Raspberry, Strawberry, Blueberry and Kiwi Lambic.
Sour Reserve Blend 5: soft sour body, buttery, a tad floral as well 4.1/5
Kiwi: no real kiwi characteristics, extremely sour and lactic 2.9/5
Raspberry: one of the freshest raspberry aromas around. Afterwards all is sour and lactic 3.4/5
Strawberry: aroma is q bit chemical strawberry, the body and taste makes one remind of the Hanssens Oudbeitje, let it be a lot more sour 3.2/5
Blueberry: the nicest and tartest of the "Lambic" series we sampled 3.5/5

These beers are not lambics and should not be called as such. It is obvious that the sour character in this beer comes from lactic fermentation rather than a complex process of different families of bacteria and yeast. The aftertaste of all of the sampled "lambic" serie have a repelling sour finish...

Bottle thnx to Geoffrey 
Blend Nr 5 
Pours unclear yellow . Good white head fades fast . 
Smell is funky , sour, buttery sweetness . 
taste is sour, oak , bit buttery sweet grainyness . Very dry . Nice , but very simple ( sour bacteria added rather than a complex mixture of different Brettanomyces - species ) .
Bottle during upland share batch #5. Golden pour with white head.nice funky tart fruit, wild tones, reminiscencent of a real gueuze. Nice funk and tart flavors.

Pours hazy straw color. Aroma of sour lemons, grapes, and oak. Soft hay undertone. Taste is perfectly sour - moderate and up front but doesn't tire the taste buds. Well balanced and top notch!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Süß säuerlicher Antrunk, nicht ganz harmonisch, die Säuerlichkeit steigt sich, aggressiv. Auch im weiteren Verlauf aggressiv, unrund. 11/8/7/9/11/8

Wow! Awesome beer from Upland. This is a blend of sours from previous years - both young and old. Nice wheat and sour lambic like quality in aroma. Slightly funky though not near the level of some of the traditional Belgian geuze and lambic. Flavor is much of the same with light hay and grains being backed by a very nice level of sourness. Finishes dry and long.

Bright hazy orange/yellow pour with a white head. Aromas of wine, oak, and acidic notes. Flavor is big time sour upfront with lots of fruit character. Very drinkable and complex. Very sour but well-balanced overall. Delicious.
At Justins house warming party. Pours orange, little nail polish, tart, medium acidity. Taste is peachy light to medium acidity, light sour fruits. Finish is medium acidic in a great way.
(750ml bottle) clearish light gold, fine white bubbles. Nose of acetone, white wine, vinous, acidulated malt. Taste of white wine, tart, cranberry, tough of vinegar in the finish.

Insanely bright orange. Slightly cloudy. Minimal head. Persimmon and kiwi acidity. Quite a fruit explosion on the nose. Holy crap this is sour. So acidic. Insanely sweet. Lots of residual sugars. Not a terrible American wild but as a gueuze, this is not even close. 
-batch 3

Bottle thanks to Will. Pours a clear orange with medium frothy white head. The aroma is sour fruit, cheese, and strong funk. Thin mouthfeel with strong funk, sour fruit, light oak and dry finish. Very impressive.

Thanks koelschtrinker! Pours a hazy brilliant orange color with an off white head. The smell is funky wood, nail polish. The taste is quite sweet with some nail polish and wood... Fruitiness is there as well ending sour and acidic. The body is light+ with nice carbonation.

Batch 03. Pours a medium golden color with a finger of white fizzy foam. Lots of stonefruit, big abrasive acidity, some barnyard must, basement funk and sour as hell... really complex unripe stonefruit is the best part of this one but the level of sourness makes this a three ounces and done kind of sour.

Bottle at 7 Eclipse Tasting. Pours a hazy orange with a small white head. Quite tart with aromas of a very tart Flemish Sour. Also notes of rose hips. Medium bodied. Medium to soft carbonation. Tart and crispy dry finish.

Bottle (Blend 2) at home - Easter Tasting. Cloudy yellow/golden - white head. Apricot sourness, high sourness, oak, lovely tartness, citrus, light vanilla, lovely - Fantastic - Leigh & Andreas you left too soon.

Bottle blend 2. Lactic, vinegar, sour grapes, lemon, damp hay, mold, apricot, stomach acid, light white glue. Medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation, medium sweet and high sour. Pretty hefty and drinkability is in the low end of the drinkability scale.

Blend four

Smell of cheese, funk and sweet fruit. The sweetness was offputting to me in flavor. Very disappointed

Hazy orange with a pale head. Aroma is oak, grape skins, green olives, funk, sharp cheese. Medium bodied, sour on the palate with a good balancing sweetness and a warming finish. Taste is apricot, sour peach candy, malt vinegar. Damn this is tasty.

Aroma: Hay, Apricots, Lactic Acid

Appearance: Hazy Golden Straw Hue, Passes Some Light, White Head, Decent Lacing

Taste: Apricots, Hay, Lactic Acid

Mouthfeel: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Semi Tart
750ml bottle Batch 4 pours a hazy gold and orange with an off white head. Mostly citrus and funk aroma. Taste is the same.
750ml bottle (Blend #2). Poured a hazy golden/amber color with an averaged sized head. Acetic, some vinegar, citrus, some woodiness, and funky.

Bottle (#4) at the RBWG grand tasting, first one of many 
Hazy golden with a small white head and some lacing. Aroma is woody, tart and fruit. Flavor is tart, acidic and dry 
Nice

RBWG14 Trip Rating #98. Bottle shared at the Grand Tasting. Pours a hazy orange color with a medium sized frothy white head. Good head retention. Aroma of earth, peppery, funk, citrus notes. Taste is tart funk, earth, citrus. Medium bodied. Nice.

Sample from Blend #4 shared by a friend. Pours a slightly hazy golden-orange color with a medium foamy off-white head that diminishes gradually. Small patches of lacing on the glass. Vinous aroma with notes of tropical fruit and wheat. Light to medium body with a tart fruity character and notes of oak, wheat and malt in the background. The finish is somewhat sour with a lingering vinous oak aftertaste. Pretty good all around.

A- pours a super hazy orange brown with no lacing and virtually no head. S- oak, white grapes, soy sauce, lemon zest, honey, light sourdough bread, sugar, vinegar, acetone, salt air, yeast, ceasar dressing. M- light to medium super sticky body with a sweet and acidic medium palate. T- sweet citrus, malts, Tropicana grovestand orange juice, lemon zest up front. Dough, vinegar and sugar on the middle. Acid grand ahold in the misplace as well. White wine grapes, butter and oak mustiness build up in the middle and carry the end. However, with some alcohol, vinegar overwhelms and fries the end. Some grass, salt and citric acid on the far end.

750ml corked and caged bottle shared by CaseyK. Thanks! Thick, unfiltered orange-tan body. Oily non-head. Classic Upland sour yeast aroma. A really nice US Sour, big lemony tart tones, US sour yeast experiment mania. Yeast depth. Super sour. Well done.
Hazy yellow pour with white creamy head. Aroma is super sour tartness. Very nice sharp acidic flavor with a touch of sweet sneaking out as well. Medium/light bodied with nice carbonation.
750-THANKS Patrick-disappearing white bubbles-cloudy orange. A-vinegar/tart/acidic, red wine. T-puckering, vinegar/tart/acidic-citric, lt malt.

Bottle to plastic cup, batch 3. Pour is murky orange, decent white head that quickly fades. Aroma of citrus, saltwater, acetic, oak, lemon, light dust. Taste is very tart, lactic, citrus, lemon, acetic. Palate is quite spicy, lower carbonation, intense acetic/lactic finish. Good but intense.

750mL blend 3 thanks to tastybeer! Murk, full haze orange with fizzing out Medium, somewhat thick foam. Ring of bubbles remain. Nose is juicy tangerine, flash of acetic acid, saltwater. Taste is quite acetic, citric, dry lime finish. Spicy bite with a long, dry, tannic finish. Quite juicy and citrus bright. Acetic content doesnt bother me too much.

Bottle shared by Jcwattsrugger. Blend 3. Pours radioactive orange. Small white head right. Nose and taste of puckering cherry vinegar, red wine, oak, orange and wild yeast. Medium body. A bit too puckering for my liking.

750mL bottle, pours a hazy golden with a small white head. Nose is pretty subtle, with oak barrels, light tartness, and even some slight fruitiness. Flavour brings out subtle barnyard funk, some vinegar, and light tartness. Not exactly like an authentic lambic, but the blend is very nice. Finishes on light notes of horse blanket, light vinegar, and some slight tartness. Great stuff, but it might be better with a more age.
Poured a cover color aromas of sour tart musk with some light tart fruit. Flavors are the same a nice beer overall that is slightly sour.

Blend 1. Lightly hazy coppery-orange body, thin off-white head, light spotty lacing. Nose shows a strong lactic, cheesy, earthy, and musty character. Flavor develops similarly but draws in some sharp lemon acidity. Medium bodied with mellow carbonation. Fairly acidic with both lactic and acetic notes contributing. Lingering pucker after each sip. While it lacks the effervescence of a good 3F/Cant/DeCam/Girardin gueuze, this does a good enough job capturing elements of the style for an American effort. While I havent had bBlends 2 or 3, I am most interested in trying Blend 4 with a similar three-year blend.

750ml bottle, shared by a friend.. Blend #3. Totally hazy cloudy peachy orange amber color. Minimal off-white head. Minimal dots of lace. Awesome big tart, apricot, tropical citrusy aroma. Great, huge citrusy very sour tart taste. So sour, its lightly drying in the finish. Bigger body. Smooth, lighter, crisp carbonation. Very dry finish. Great stuff. Very sour, lightly biting, dry finish, but very good. Great, big sour sour.

Pours a clear orange with a small rim and film for a cover and not much lacing. Aroma is acetic, woody, cheesy and overall wild. Taste is acetic (way too much for its own good), fruity and overall a bit harsh to me. Body was medium and carbonation also. Ok... The fruited lambics are way beyond what this has offered!
BLEND 3: Hautement plus dacidité en bouche quau nez, un brett gras et un fromage délicat. La morsure acétique est profonde mais la complexité suit sans problème, très solide.

batch 3. pours hazy light golden, chunkless as opposed to their fruit lambics, with a small white head, some retention and lacing. cheese, winey oakiness, hint of bourbon vanilla, acetic fruitiness, buttery lightly sweet wheat and malts, very dusty, fruity - grapes, herbs and grass. bright carbonation, light body - very oily in fact, acetic bite and grapefruity finish - tad harsh and puckering. an excellent lambic base to blend in fruits but it seems to be a bit sugary and acetic by itself. still very complex and solid..

Bottle (750 ml). Batch 3 (2013). Thanks to Randall for this one! Slightly hazy golden/orange with no head and no lacing. Aroma is buttery with red wine (its almost smell like bourbon, weird), brettanomyces and fruity notes. Taste is moderately sweet and acetic with brettanomyces, butter (way less than in the aroma), fruits, red wine and residual sugar). Medium to full body. Low to moderate carbonation. Slightly winey mouthfeel. Good American Wild Ale. Its not as good as their best fruited "lambics" in which the fruits are shining and hiding the residual sugar. Unique Gueuze/Wild Ale.

FROM NOTES: July 20, 12
Poured into a taster glass from a bomber.

A: Strong lactic notes with just a touch of plums, cherries, peaches, apricots and nectarines in the background.
A: Pours a very hazy orange-gold color.
T: Follows nose with more fruit coming out as it warms.
P: Light body with heavy lactic acid through the finish.
O: Good, not great, gueuze

Bottle courtesy of jcartamdg. Pours a murky yellow-orange with a white head. Nose is kumquat, persimmon, citrus, tartness, vinegar, funk, oak, vinous character, and mystery, Flavor is similar with citrus, kumquat, funk, tartness, persimmons, oak, vinous character, and vinegar. As complex as the murky depths from which it issues forth. Wow. Full in body and very sour.

Batch 3. Pours cloudy pale amber with a small off white head. Aroma is intense sour sweet honey fruity funky stable cellar. Flavor is sour lemon juice yet sweet fruity and balances out towards the finish. Some vinegar acidy touch just making it more interesting.

Pours a bright gold with no head. Aroma of vinegar, oak, apricot and kumquats. Taste is sour, citrus, apricots, kumquats. Oak and funk. Really nice, really sour

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Blend 2. The pour has a lot of carbonation and a bright orange. The aroma is strong sour. The taste is a nice mellow sour. A good drink. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, 08/08/2013, batch 3, thanks to franch and ceight. Pours hazy dark orange, white head dies quickly, thin lacing. Aroma is sour malts, strong citric tartness, very acetic, earthy funk and wood. Taste is puckering, tart lemon, orange, pear, lingering sweetness with acetone, vinegar, subtle oak, but really a bit harsh for me. Medium body. Not balanced, overly acetic, not really something I dig a lot.

750ml bottle shared by Pat. Batch 3. Thanks! Pours a orangey amber color with a thin white head. Aroma is citric, lemon, floral. Medium on the palate with light carbonation. Not quite flat, but very light. Flavor is sour, fruity, lemon, oak, more sour, with a light oaky finish. A bit one dimensional, but a nice sour.
Tasted from bomber brought to the lake by nephew Patrick....thanks. Definite sour initial taste...good but not great....thanks Pat....

Batch 2. Pour is glowing orange, light haze, and tight white head. Nose is orange citrus and tangerine, juicy wine and barrel, light musk and cheese and seemingly acetic. Taste is juicy, oily, orange citrus and tangerine, wine barrel and oak, light cheese moving to acetic acid. Burn in finish, not horrible but increasing, semi dry, assertive carbonation and a bit heavy on the body.
Batch 2, 750 ml bottle. Pours a hazy copper with a white ring of foam. I get some vanilla on top of a ligtly funky lactic tartness. Oak comes through thickly. Mildly sour finish.

750 ml bottle shared by jeremy.  Pours a hazy dark golden color with a medium sized white head.  The aroma is a big sour/tart opening, citrus, funk, acidic with hints of vinegar and wood.  The flavor is definitely sour, funky, fruity vinegar, acidic, wood, and tart fruits.  A solid example of an American gueze.  Batch 2.
Batch 3. This one is intensely vinegary sour with a solid funk level. Very tasty.
Bottle. Looks pretty good. Tastes sweet, sour, stomach acid. Full mouthfeel. A really satisfying beer. Great.

pours a hazy gold .. mild foam .. lacing is good .. . tart hay, flowers, and sour straw .. . good mouth feel .. . a very good wild ale 

.. . . im a farmer rater so you know ive been kickin that shit all day!!

Bottle @ a recent bottle share...  Poured golden/orange with an off-white head.  Lots of oak going on here with acidic tartness, musky yeast spices, and a pickled juice sort of character.  Lots of brett notes to keep it interesting.

Small sampler sent to me from queenholly.  Blend 2.  Thanks Rebekah!  The pour is a dirty brown color with no head.  This smells of sour jolly ranchers with some buggy musty funk and apple cider.  The flavors are not as sour as the aroma suggests but theres enough to strike the senses.  A bit acetic, but nothing over the top, citric lemon notes mingle in, with wood, apple cider, and a slick body.  Ive had a few of Uplands other Lambics before and wasnt all that impressed with those.  But this one is really quite good and way better than what Ive had from Upland before.

Tiny bubbled, hazy orange gold.
Very funky, sharp tartness.
Flavour is yeasty,  sweetened vinegar.
Tingly, acidic, bretty, fruity.
Nice sour jolt.

Consolation beer while watching Notre Dames pathetic performance against Alabama. Oh well. Thank god the beer was better than the game. Cloudy amber orange color, small bubble head. Aroma of sour and dusty apricot, peach, citrus. Taste is sour and earthy summer fruit. Slightly acetic but tasty.

bright orange, large bubbled white head dies quick, decent lacing. Acetic and dark dough nose leads to berry (cherry, blueberry) and a masking glue/sawdust note with playdoh hints. Flavor is acetic up front, lactic masking in yogurt and citrus before finish burns a bit with a doughy strawberry finish.

Bottle - Blend 2.  Funky bretty barnyard and tart cidery aroma.  Cloudy golden with a small white head. Funky bretty yeast, acetic cidery flavor, which was smoothed and mellow with some very slight sweetness. Medium body, moderate carbonation.

Bottle.  Strong barnyard Brett  and a blend of lactic and acetic acids in the aroma.  Hazy golden yellow with moderate head.  Tart vinegar malt flavor with a hint of sweetness.   Vinegar finish.  A Brett lovers dream.

Shared by Thorpe429. Thanks Mike. I am so grateful to try this, since I accidentally clicked the "back" button when finalizing my order for this. 

The beer is hazy and light orange colored with a small, fleeting, wispy head. Nice aroma consisting of wild yeast, citrus, grass, wheat. Acetic and lactic feel on the palate with low carbonation. Pretty good flavor. Definitely smells and tastes like an Upland beer. Very good, but not world class. Definitely one of the better gueuze examples to emerge from the U.S.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-19-2012

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2012 Blend 1 bottle.  Phaleslu made his presence felt by leaving this nice little present.   excited to try this indana gueuze beer.  pours a clear orange copper with a quickly dissipating offwhite head.   intial aroma has a strong cheesy, old leather, cheesecloth, leading into a deep apple cider,   apricot, and moderately sharp lemon sourness.    taste is moderate-heavy lemon and sour apple sourness with a juicy apple cider stronghold.   not flat to be sure, but carbonation is low.  would prefer a bit more carbonation.  maybe a 7 on the "how sour is it?" scale. definitely wouldnt want it to be any more sour than this, but it is still relatively chuggable.  what i am trying to say is the following:  it is on the sour side to be sure, but they strike a nice balance while they are on that side with the apple and apricot fruitiness.     so it seems to work just fine.  if i were to taste this blind, i would imagine i would say it is an lemon, leather, apple cider american sour ale, not a gueuze.   a pleasant, easy drinkin  apricot, apple cider sour ale beer.   not a good to-style gueuze, but i  happen to like it as an american sour ale.   neat to try.  Thanks again peter.   beers like this dont grow on trees, they morph into my belly.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2013 Batch 2. Funky and lactic in the nose; translates perfectly into the taste. Hay & barnyard funk butt up against bright citrus notes. Highly lactic and acetic with that distinctively American yeast flavor. Another excellent sour from Upland!
19th October 2012THE Sour and Saison tasting. Cloudy amber beer, little cream coloured head. Light palate, dry and crisp. Lemony citrus with a white wine tang. Sharp acidic finish. Okay.

Bottle @ THE Sour and Saison Tasting. The pH in the room dropped by a good few points when we opened this...The pours a hazy golden amber with a medium white head. The nose is super sweet and tart. Plenty of aggressive acidity. Notes of wood, plenty of lemon peel, some butterscotch candy. The taste starts sweet - plenty of candied lemon and butterscotch, wood. This flames out in the finish into heavy acetic lemon juice, warhead candy. Tart and mildly woody. Ragged, combative flavors. The bodys not particularly smooth, the flavors not fully in harmony. Overall, an interesting beer. Its full of personality, but certainly uneven. This was tried alongside a murderers row of top sours, which certainly didnt help its case. OK.

Bottle (Batch #2) at THE Sour and Saison Tasting, London. Many thanks to Jack! Pours cloudy gold with a light, white cream head. Funky nose with sweat, light vinegar, some leather. Medium sweet flavor with high acidity, a bit more vinegar, mellow grass, some sugar. Medium bodied with average to high carbonation. Stinging finish with plenty of acidic vinegar, some fruity sugars. Sits a bit heavy on the palate. Lingering sugary fruits and strong tartness. Not bad overall, but a touch heavy.

Bottle (batch #2) thanks to jackl, at THE sour tasting (part 1). It pours hazy golden yellow, with a small white film. The nose is slightly sulphurous, tart, butter, menthol aspect, vanilla, almond and coconut. The taste is lemon, sour apricot, deep vinegar burn, sticky sweetness, high acidity, mouth-puckering tartness, vomit and coconut water, with an acidic finish. Medium body, prickly carbonation and quite a heavy mouth-feel. Somewhat cloying. I like the tartness, but it is very one-dimensional. Didnt stand up-well against proper Belgian gueuzes.

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2013 Bottle, generously shared by Matt.  Cloudy dehydrated pee in color with a white head.  Some autolysis (burnt rubber) in the nose.  Uber tart, think sour patch kids or nuclear war heads.  Vinegar and salt notes.  Not my thing. (original rating 3)
Re-rate (blend 3) Clear yellow pour with a white head.  Tart sour biatch with some hints of salt.  Above average body and mouthfeel.  Tart and sour, but tasty...

Bottle... This beer rocks! Murky peach-colored ale with no head. The nose offers big-time fruitiness and acidity  lemon and apricot  with a little vanilla. Medium to full-bodied with a silky mouthfeel and tingly carbonation. The flavor is stupid acidic and fruity - sour cherry and peach  with a small splash of white wine vinegar. Finishes tart and yeasty. Thanks go out to landhoney for reeling in and sharing this world class bottle of beer!

750 ml at GTMW 2012

I timed it perfectly to get a pour from one of a handful of bottles brought to the Great Taste by Upland. This was one of the beers that was worth the price of admission. An excellent world class sour Batch #2 makes me wish I was able to try the first at some point.

Aroma / Appearance - The cloudy golden body was probably partially due to agitation of the bottle. It looked like it tasted - a sharp gueuze in a sample glass. Lemons and a tart vinegary note bit at the senses.

Flavor / Palate - Tart and to the point this was intense from the first sip. I cant imagine drinking an entire bottle alone. The dry finish tastes like a sharp acidic champagne complete with traces of carbonation. Based on this I cant wait until Upland is able to turn their old facility into a full time sour factory.

Rating 4200! 8/11/12. GTMW. I can only assume the bottle was the most recent release. Very nice golden pour with a nice fluffy barely off-white head and good lacing. Awesome aroma of funk, oak, vanilla, cream, fruitiness, grapes, and sourness. The flavor matches with more tartness and fruitiness along with a bit of wood and vanilla. Great stuff!

Bottle of Blend 1 sampled at Muckfest III. Clear, yet chunky orange color with no head. Aroma of sourness and pepper with some citrus. Malt and slight honey on the tongue first, then heavy pepperiness before a fruity and sour finish.
Poured from a 750 ml bottle. Very very sour beer. Obvious that this was barrel aged. A dry beer that I unfortunately didnt enjoy as much as their lambics.

Beer Bloggers Conference 2012 
Reddish in color, clear with no head.  Big sour and sweet aroma.  Lots of barrel aging you can tell this was a special beer with lots of love.  Very well blended brew.  Very tasty.

Batch 1 bottle shared at Muckfest III by TheAlum...thanks Adam! - Pours hazy amber with a ring of white head. Nose has cheese, citrus funk, and a vinegary tartness. Taste is puckeringly tart, really lemon-forward with lots of vinegar tartness. Hints of oak. Pretty good stuff, though that sourness was pretty intense.

Bottle to taster (blend #2; thanks jmborggren). Looks good; a hazy orange with thin lacing. Smells solid; spicy and a little funky. Tastes sour and funky with a good mouthfeel. Good, but not as good as I remember blend #1 being (which, to be fair, was aged longer).

Blend #2. Pour out of bottle at Avery Sourfest 2012, pour is hazy yellow-golden with white head, aroma brought notes of big lactic and lemony sour, some nice cheesy, horseblanket funk, oak and vanilla come through with some lemon, slight bready and yeast notes.  Taste unfortunately brings some acetic notes which burn the throat, but overall nice with some funky cheese and horse, hints of biscuit with a nice lemony lactic sour, some vanilla, oak come through as well.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2012 Bottle shared by jmborggren. Poured hazy golden color with an average fizzy white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Moderate to heavy complex wood, yeast and sour citrus aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy sour & sweet fruit flavor with a medium to heavy sweet & sour finish of moderate to long duration. Standout drinkable brew.

(750ml bottle, blend #2)  Pours a cloudy golden body with a medium white head.  Aroma of vanilla, grapefruit, perfume, and lemon.  Flavor of grapefruit, earth, sweet tarts, lemon, and green apple with a dry finish.

Bottle at Avery Sour Fest 3.  Pours hazy orange with a light, frothy white head, medium retention with light lacing.  Aroma is hay and straw malt, acetic vinegar, light barnyard notes, grapes and light oak.  Flavor is sour acetic grapes, light butyric acid, light malt, horse blanket and barnyard notes with a dry finish.  Medium body and carbonation.

750 ml bottle shared by Aubrey Joe- thanks a ton, Joe! I have one of these at home, too, but I am not sure which blend- I think 1. Anyway, this one pours a hazy, dull yellow-gold color with a small white ring and film for a head. Aroma of lemon, grass and herbs, lactic yogurt, oak, and straw. Flavor of lemon, peach, herbs, oak, and more lactic yogurty character. Medium-bodied, with a tart, dry mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. So nice and easy to sip. Loved this one.

Bottle @ Avery SourFest III. One of the highlights of the fest for me. Somewhat hazy/cloudy yellow appearance with a white head. Quite sour, lemon citrusy, musty, barnyard, lactic aroma. Intensely sour, lemon, vanilla, pineapple, a bit cheesy, light stone fruity flavor. I could see how this one would have varied opinions, but its up my alley.

Tap at 3rd Annual Boulder Sourfest (06-02-2012). Poured a beautiful, hazy peach color with little-to-no head. Smell is very funky/bretty, lacto, and some acetic notes. Very sour apricot/peach taste, with hints of brett and lemon peel. Medium palate with soft carbonation. Very solid sour.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2012 batch 2, bottle pour at Avery SourFest.  hazed and murky golden body with a small white head. musty nose with notes of chalk, mold spores, damp hay, high lactic acid and strong bile / butyric acid. prickly sharp acetic vinegar acid throughout, growing stronger late. sadly this is nothing like Belgian lambic, its far too acetic and the butyric acid (rancid, sweaty bile) and ethyl butyrate esters (tropical fruits) are off-putting.

Bottle; blend #2. Pours cloudy gold wig thin, fizzy white head; short retention and spare lacing. Aroma is strong sour fruit, grassy notes, biscuit malt, oak, and light spice. Flavor is sour and tart fruit forward with supporting sweet malt; dry, sour finish. Light body, medium carbonation, and low warmth.

Served in a SAVOR wine glass.

Pours a deep golden color with a short white head that fizzes out quickly and doesnt leave anything behind. The nose carries some strong lactic notes with just a touch of stone fruits in the background. Flavor is similar with more fruit coming out as it warms. Light body with heavy lactic acid through the finish. Very dry. Gets better as it warms, but the focus is too much on acidity without the underlying funk, earthiness, and complexity.

Tart citrus aroma with mild funk on the nose and hints of acetic aromas.  Pours golden blonde with a white head.  Lemony tart upfront with some acetic notes followed by mild vinegar notes and citrus peel in the finish.  A little acetic but overall a nice sour!

Bottle... Dark gold, light off white head... Lactic nose, yogurt, stone fruits, quite nice... taste is a bit lighter, not as sour still lots of yogurt, a little apricot, aroma is better than the nose, solid 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle thanks to Ari. Pours a near clear with a white head that starts at the edges and remains throughout the beer. Aroma is full of sour fruit, acid and a good amount funk and a hint of lemon. Flavor begins with really sour fruit with some funk, but mainly acid that burns a bit on the back of the throat.

Simply the best sour ale Ive had to date. The sour of this beer hits up front and mellows on the back of the tongue. Hints of lemon and citrus and a slightly floral funkiness. Light orange pour with with light, rather quickly disapating head. Of all of Uplands Sour offerings, this is the best (as it should be given the meticulous blending that it sounds like they did).

The pour is a murky orange-ish color with a finger of white head.  Smells intensely lactic and lemony.  Quite a bit of lemon peel and green apple, maybe a little bit of funk (hay and grass).  A few notes of oak, too.  The flavor is similarly heavy on the lemon tartness and lactic acidity.  Minimal funk notes, maybe a touch of vinegar.  Medium body and medium to high carbonation.
Shared a bottle. Aroma is tart, almost apricot tart aroma with a tinge of citric notes, lactic characteristics. Very flavorful, like a crisp, green apple. Funky notes, sour, enjoyable.

(750ml bottle from Patchmaster.  Thanks Blair!).  Pours a hazy apricot color with a white head.  Aroma is apricot, cheese, wood, funkalisciousness.  Taste is sour, vinegar and fruit.  Medium bodied with a dry finish.  Easily the best lambic produced by Upland  Good God!  This stuff is great.
Light orange pour. Aroma has cheese, apricot, peach, vinegar.  Flavor is loaded with sour goodness, peaches, cheesy goodness. Yessss!

Sampled during Darkness Day 2011 in Brooklyn, MN. Pours a hazy coppery brown colored brew with an average sized off-white head that quickly dissipated to a thin white ring and film top. Aroma of lemon zest,  cheddar cheese, a hint of tropical fruit and a little barnyard funk. Taste is medium bodied, flavors of tart tropical fruit, cheese, some lemon zest, some tart apple and plenty of sour yeast.  Finish is semi-dry, funky sour with some light lemon and vanilla aftertaste.

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2012 750 ml bottle from the Indy Tasting Room (Indianapolis, IN). BLEND #1. Thanks to Kan for picking up my reserves. Pours a nice darker golden muted hue, a bit murky and dark for the color with a decent offwhite frothy head dies to thicker ring, laces ok. Aromas are lemons and yogurt, a light hay and grassy element, some sweeter bread, with more sourness, gentle bretty dryness and funk. Aromas grow a bit more potent as it warms, the brett and sour lemon comes forward, the yogurt comes a bit forward too, but lemony sourness and lactic acid grows. Brett offers healthy cheesiness, Bleu cheese, barnyard, with a touch of a warning of acedic elements. Initial is a nice bite of sourness up front, lemons and crab apples mix with lactic acidity, touches of hay, some oranges, and grass. Sourness bites, but falls back into the middle, throwing some touches of brett, hay, and straw. Sourness keeps on keeping on, nothing overbearing or acedic. Really nice sour bite, as the finish leaves some dryness, yogurt, and more sourness lingering into the finish. Brett plays second fiddle here, sourness asserting itself, with a touch of body so as not to be a one trick pony. Finish has touches of dough and dry bread, some sourdough elements. Dry and sour. My only qualm might be the Brett falling a little too far back. Sour and potent, but not overbearing into the overly acedic side. A funky nose but not into the body. A very nice beer, but lacks the complexity the nose seemed to promise. Still its tasty, providing a bite of sourness. Best of any Upland Sour/Wild offering Ive had to date (which is all of them!)

750ml bottle. Thanks to Adam for sharing one of his procured bottles... Pours a hazy, mostly opaque, copper orange brown and topped with a medium fluffy head that quickly receded leaving a wispy film...่aroma hits first with a lactic sourness, pretty acidic and sour. A socky funkiness also permeates and emitted with a few swirls. Some coconut to pair with the footy funk as well as some acetone surfacing late... Flavors are similar but not totally consistent perhaps deviating slightly from the nose.  Above average American wild lactic sourness with just a mild cheesiness. Not complex but pretty well executed. aggressively sour but not verly so with no acetone presence. Body is just shy of medium with a decent level of lively carbonation.

Blend #1.  750ml bottle pours a cloudy gold with a thin, fizzy, white head.  Nose is really authentic.  Smells just like the great Gueuzes of Belgium, grassy, band aid, vinegar, hay, lemons, flowers.  A complete brett bomb.  Flavor is very tart, lemon peel, grapefruit, apple cider vinegar, grass, hay.  Full bodied, acetic finish.  Lots of vinegar on the finish which takes away from this beer just a bit.  A real accomplishment for Upland.  Perhaps the best American Gueuze.
